items.title: Correct encoding not being used when using pisaStory to create a story of flowables
items.body:
pisaStory uses html5lib to parse HTML and convert it into a reportlab story. However, when a string is passed to pisaStory, it converts it to a byte stream using utf-8 encoding but does not pass this information on to html5lib's parser. On the other hand, html5lib uses "windows-1252" as the default encoding to read the data back resulting in incorrect decoding.

eg.
```python3
string = '‘the Company’ \xa0 Fiancée'
from xhtml2pdf.document import pisaStory
pisaStory(string).story[0].text
# This gives the output
# â€˜the Companyâ€™ \xa0 FiancÃ©e
```

This bug can easily be fixed by ensuring the encoding is passed from xhtml2pdf to html5lib's parser as the `transport_encoding` parameter

```python3
# line 739 in xhtml2pdf/parser.py
document = parser.parse(
    src, transport_encoding=encoding
)
```

items.title: ValueError: Unknown color False when using borders
items.body:
I'm converting HTML including a header tag:
`<h2 style="border:1px solid black; background:#dddddd;">`

During conversion I'm receiving an error 
`ValueError: Unknown color False`

Looking into this a bit I'm seeing borderLeftColor being set to "False" based on the value of "-pdf-outline-open" on line 584 of parser.py
`
transform_attrs(context.frag,
                        (
                            ("keepWithNext", "-pdf-keep-with-next"),
                            ("outline", "-pdf-outline"),
                            ("borderLeftColor", "-pdf-outline-open"),
                        ),
                        context.cssAttr,
                        getBool
                        )
`

This is also the case for another H1 tag with no border attribute set. However, without a border style it doesn't appear to trigger the error.

I don't know enough about the library to know why this extra transformation would be desired, but commenting it out fixes my issue.

items.title: Error while decoding Unipath Path
items.body:
I'm using xhtml2pdf and Unipath in a Django application. In this application, the path for static files is defined as a Path object, instead of a string. When trying to render an image in a pdf, I get this exception:

> 'Path' object has no attribute 'decode'

I see that the class pisaFileObject tries to decode its uri parameter when it is not a string, but exceptions in this decoding attempt are not controlled:

https://github.com/xhtml2pdf/xhtml2pdf/blob/3a1bec73019ed1d8965ca53abfc6946ff5944d41/xhtml2pdf/util.py#L599

Should this be considered a bug in xhtml2pdf? If not, how could I use Unipath and xhtml2pdf together?

When I try to convert HTML to PDF I have this error: "CSRF token missing or incorrect."

> Reason given for failure:
> 
>     CSRF token missing or incorrect.
>     
> 
> In general, this can occur when there is a genuine Cross Site Request Forgery, or when Django's CSRF mechanism has not been used correctly. For POST forms, you need to ensure:
> 
>     Your browser is accepting cookies.
>     The view function passes a request to the template's render method.
>     In the template, there is a {% csrf_token %} template tag inside each POST form that targets an internal URL.
>     If you are not using CsrfViewMiddleware, then you must use csrf_protect on any views that use the csrf_token template tag, as well as those that accept the POST data.
>     The form has a valid CSRF token. After logging in in another browser tab or hitting the back button after a login, you may need to reload the page with the form, because the token is rotated after a login.
> 
> You're seeing the help section of this page because you have DEBUG = True in your Django settings file. Change that to False, and only the initial error message will be displayed.
> 
> You can customize this page using the CSRF_FAILURE_VIEW setting.

items.title: AttributeError: 'bytes' object has no attribute 'encode'
items.body:
Hi,

We are working on a Django project that uses django-easy-pdf - which in turns uses xhtml2pdf - to render a pdf. It has been working great untill it recently broke. Looking at the traceback I believe the error is in xhtml2pdf and not easy_pdf. 

To be more specific I suspect commit 8637f24 has broken it. I'm getting `AttributeError: 'bytes' object has no attribute 'encode'` with the traceback found below. 

I'm not very familiar with working on the level of byte-objects, so I'm not entirely sure how this is all supposed to work. items.title: How can I set PDF meta-data
Error when in addFromFile using file-like object
items.body:
When I try to add a pdf from a file using
`pdf.addFromFile(open(f, "rb"))`

I get this error `'file' object has no attribute 'encode'`.
Taking a look at the code, I saw that `self.addFromURI(f)` is always called, even when f is a file-like obj. Shouldn't the code

```
def addFromFile(self, f):
    if hasattr(f, "read"):
        self.files.append(f)
    self.addFromURI(f)
```

be changed to

```
def addFromFile(self, f):
    if hasattr(f, "read"):
        self.files.append(f)
    else:
        self.addFromURI(f)
```

items.title: @page size portrait warning
items.body:
According to usage.rst @page size can take an orientation component of portrait or landscape. The code in context.py only accepts landscape; portrait does work but logs a warning.

WARNING:xhtml2pdf:Unknown size value for @page

atPage() should have another clause in its tests for valueStr, if it equals "portrait" set isLandscape to False.
